bibl.title: Despatch from Albert Bushnell to William M. Evarts, February 1, 1878
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
<div1 xml:lang="en" type="document"
<pb facs="20170615_143214" Sir,
I have the honor to ackknowledge the receipt of your Despatch Nov. 11th haveing State, October 28,1878, on the 10th of Janurary 1879, about thus month from the have it was written. Our mails during the past year, have been irregular with are essential of siz to eight weeks, between them. The last serviced was just two months, Your Loerport to Gaboon. The streamers now having ones government subsidy, call at numerous ports on the Coast often are delayed in Freight. There on a merchant steamers which will take these dispatches that make much quicker passages, but it brings no mails.
The inequality + detention of our mails is my apology for asking for been of absence so long in advance. I doubt the leave of absence has granted + is intent for Gaboon. I hope all be *unclear* of next extension from Liverport *unclear* here on to the vesself for offering *unclear row*
<pb facs="20170615_143233"
and all returns till may. Although I have nominated Rev. S. HE. Murphy as vice Commercial Agent, + doubt not his appointment has been made; I do not like to leave my post, till I have receieved my leave of absence; + shall not, unless the state of my health imperitively demands it my medical advisor- The French Surgeon in Chief of the COlony- assured this morning that my departure ought noy be long postponed.
I beg to remain Sir; Respectfully, Your obident Servant Albert, Bushnell United, S. Com. Agent
